In the background, there was a framed monochrome photograph of Ryan Giggs triumphantly hoisting the European Cup on the Manchester Airport tarmac in 2008. Peer closer and Darren is visible in the background on the passenger boarding steps.
On the same day, Jack stood on the Old Trafford pitch and brandished his own shirt. That was one way to tell which is which.

headline: Scoring 100 goals a season and sharing a Roy Keane trait - Dan Gore's Manchester United journey
body: Man United youngster Dan Gore has made excellent progress over the last 18 months, so the MEN spoke to two of his former coaches at Burnley to discuss his journey to the first-team at Old Trafford.
Dan Gore couldn't help but smile throughout his post-match interview after making his Manchester United debut.

Gore made his senior bow against Crystal Palace in the Carabao Cup and he fought an excitable grin as he answered questions. The game also coincided with his 19th birthday and his family were present to enjoy the occasion, which Gore described as 'truly special' after growing up supporting the club.

“It tops the list of birthdays," Gore said while trying to keep his composure. "I don’t think words can describe that feeling, seeing the fans, it is everything you’ve dreamed of, coming true. It means everything."
Gore became the 247th player to make his debut from the academy that night, reward for making excellent progress and convincing Erik ten Hag he was ready.
He trained with the first-team for 12 weeks before his debut and is known to 'train every day like his life depends on it', something which his former coaches at Burnley loved about him.

Although Gore is a Salford-lad and he idolised Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo when he was a kid, he only joined United in 2018, having previously been at Burnley where he played as a forward, not a midfielder.

"He first came through the door when he was seven or eight," Lewis Craig told the Manchester Evening News. "Burnley were very good at recruiting the Scouse and Manc kids and Dan was a raw, inner-city Manchester lad.

"Those types seemed to have that little bit more extra bite than your local kids. He was a forward when he came to us and he’d either play wide left or right or as the number nine and he was the top scorer through his age groups.

"He was quick and very strong for his size. He always had aggression and he was one of the kids who played on the edge, in terms of maybe making the odd bad challenge, but it was interesting because he was always respectful.

"He had great finishing ability in his younger years, one-on-one, going past people and he always had that bit where he was a winner. If he was getting beat, there was nobody on the pitch who hated it more and you could see that fire in him. Dan had that brilliant, real f****** horrible side to him, but he'd always be respectful with coaches and it wasn't a surprise when I saw him three months ago and he ran over and gave me a hug when I hadn’t seen him for years."

Gore joined United at 13 and the decision was made to drop him deeper into midfield. "My last day working for Burnley, I had to deliver his review to his dad," Craig said when asked about his position change.

"Although he was a great striker, I didn’t think he scored poachers goals, like your Harry Kane or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. He scored amazing goals and he was off the charts, but I thought he could be a better instinctive finisher.

"I remember his dad saying thank you because all he'd had for a couple of years was people telling him how good he was and nobody had said things to work on. He was prolific and he’d beat a few men and fire one into the top corner, but if someone wrapped a ball across the 18-yard box at speed, he probably didn’t have that instinctive finish in him every time.

"But he worked on it religiously. He always worked on stuff and he was in training early, even as a kid. I never pictured him as a midfielder because although his awareness was decent, it's different playing in that role. He’s developed his awareness now and when I see him driving the ball in midfield, it’s similar to how he played back then."
Mike Hargreaves, who considers Gore as the best young player he's encountered, is another former Burnley coach who worked with the youngster and he spoke to the MEN about that period.

"I worked with Danny at Burnley from Under-9s to Under-12s and I took that age group all the way through, so I worked with him for quite a while, and outside of Burnley with my own coaching," Hargreaves said.

"Some of the things I’ve seen him do for United, he’s been doing since back then. He’s dropped deeper now, but when he played up front for Burnley he'd score over 100 goals each season and I’m not even exaggerating.

"There was a game at Blackburn once when we built possession well, Dan picked the ball up inside his own half and he just started running past people and he ended up finishing it off, which was unbelievable. There was another time when he faced someone up, stopped the ball dead and did the Yannick Bolaise showboating thing when he bent down and flicked the grass, so he had a little bit of cheekiness about him.

"He was a matchwinner and they were a really good group. I always thought It was just a matter of time before United would come in for him and I always expected that. I can’t think of many times he didn't have a good day."

Hargreaves continued: "His real stand-out qualities were he was hard-working, aggressive, he put himself about and he was a really exciting dribbler. He was fantastic with the ball and capable of sprinting repeatedly. His speed endurance was phenomenal, even at those ages. His attitude was great and he was demanding of his teammates and the standards of the session.

"Towards the end of Under-11s, we had a tournament on Blackpool’s pitch and it was a full-day affair. We played United in the final of that and Danny scored. They were just completely top draw that day as a group.

"I remember building up to that tournament for a few weeks and reiterating what we were building up to and you’d see a change in him, almost like a switch being flicked and a refocus. You could see he wanted to win."
The burning desire to improve and win has seen Gore become a member of the first-team squad with Ten Hag in charge and he's worn the captain's armband when playing in academy matches this season.

"He’s captain material I'd say," Craig added. "Almost like your old-school Roy Keane type with hard challenges, but he’s got unbelievable quality on the ball because he was a forward in the past as well.

"In that Under-21 group at United, there have been the likes of Shola Shoretire and Isak Hasen-Aaroen but it seems like there's been something missing in them, which doesn’t seem to be the case with Dan. If you leave him in an environment long enough he thrives and I think it's fair to say that Dan wasn’t a Burnley type of player, in the sense that he was probably beyond Burnley in terms of his ability.

"He would have played for Burnley’s first-team if he was still there and Sean Dyche would have been all over him, but there was always an acceptance of Dan was Salford, Man United and there were murmurings going on in the background. Kids get poached in academies all the time, but I think Burnley got looked after with the deal when he did go over. And I think he was given certain guarantees because United knew the talent they were getting."

Gore was part of the FA Youth Cup winning side in 2022 and although Alejandro Garnacho was the poster boy of that campaign, his partnership with Kobbie Mainoo in midfield was instrumental in the success. More than 60,000 supporters watched the final at Old Trafford and Gore kissed the badge when the full time whistle went. It wasn't a surprise for a boy who used to wear a red thermal vest under his Burnley shirt.
"You can tell what Manchester United means to him when he plays," Craig said. "I went to the Youth Cup final and I just thought he was outstanding, doing the horrible side of the game really well.

"I thought out of possession, Dan was excellent, picking up second balls and showing all the stuff he's added to his game as a midfielder and you can see he's got a real understanding of the game now."

Hargreaves was also in the crowd and he briefly talked to Gore during the celebrations. "I saw him right at the end when they were doing the lap of honour because I was sitting near the front, so I went down and shouted.

"He said 'aaaah Mike!' and I congratulated him, so it was nice to have that moment and I did have to laugh because near the end of the Youth Cup final, he was tapping his head and telling people to focus.

"That’s stuck with me because it’s something I do myself. We had great times at Burnley and he was the star of the group. I’ve got a great relationship with him and his dad, who was always very grateful for us looking after him."

Gore has been on an upward trajectory since and Bruno Fernandes is understood to have been very welcoming to the youngster, taking a hands-on role in his integration into the first-team. Sources have also indicated Jonny Evans has been especially supportive and offered Gore plenty of advice since they started training together in mid-July, which the 19-year-old has appreciated.

"You’re around top players every day at United and you either adapt or die," Craig said. "Even if he ends up making 100 appearances for United in the Premier League or with another club, he'll get the most out of himself.
"Ten Hag has been known for developing youngsters at Ajax and he doesn’t put people in who aren’t good enough. I'm really proud of him and it's lovely when you bump into him, or get a text."

Hargreaves echoed those comments: "It’s been brilliant to see him progress and I’m a United fan myself, so I'm extremely pleased because it's more than he deserves. I genuinely think he embodies what a United player should be, bringing excitement, being hard-working and holding himself in the right way."

Gore recently shaved his head - going for a buzzcut style - and there was a large smile on his face when he revealed his new haircut to his amused teammates at Carrington. That wide grin doesn't seem to be going away anytime soon.

headline: Manchester United make decision on Amad's future
body: Amad joined Man United from Atalanta in October 2020 but he has only played 10 times for the club.
Manchester United are planning to keep Amad beyond the closure of the January transfer window.
United expect Facundo Pellistri to join Granada on loan and believe Amad has an important role to play in the squad.
Amad, 21, made his first United appearance in more than two years as a substitute in the 2-1 defeat to Nottingham Forest on January 30.
The Ivory Coast international missed the FA Cup third round win against Wigan Athletic through illness and he could return to the squad for the fourth round tie at Newport County next week.
United signed Amad for £19million rising to £37m from Atalanta on transfer deadline day in October 2020 and the winger has played 10 times for the club.
EXCLUSIVE: Brailsford meeting former United staff with 'brutal' changes planned

Amad spent the second half of the 2021-22 season on loan at Rangers and shone during a season-long loan at Sunderland last term. Amad scored 14 goals in 42 games for the Championship side as Sunderland reached the play-offs.
Pellistri was due to leave on loan in the summer but ended up remaining at United after Amad sustained a knee injury in the pre-season win against Arsenal in July.
Amad returned to training in early December and he performed creditably off the bench in the loss at Forest.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo has done something no other Manchester United player has done under Erik ten Hag
body: Man United recorded their first Premier League win of 2024 on Thursday night, beating Wolves 4-3 at Molineux, but it must mark a turning point in their season.
As a flurry of Manchester United supporters started to vacate their golden seats at Molineux, their golden boy forced them to come running back.

With 97 minutes on the clock, Kobbie Mainoo could not have selected a better moment to score his first-ever Premier League goal. Pedro Neto's 95th-minute equaliser had, it seemed, earned Wolves a point, denying United a win that would have been fully merited.

But as United's supporters prepared to criticise those all too familiar failings, such as wasted opportunities and their soft underbelly, Mainoo changed the mindset with a moment of individual brilliance. After dodging two challenges, he entered the penalty area, bent a right-footed effort towards the far corner and sent the away end barmy.

United, to their credit, had produced some of the best football they had played all season, particularly in the first half. They looked menacing every time they went forward, with full-backs Diogo Dalot and Luke Shaw providing forward runs to support Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford.

Rasmus Hojlund, who netted the second goal as a result of one of Shaw's darts to the byline, was everywhere, chasing every ball and providing a focal point at the top end of the pitch for United to aim at. His combination play with Rashford and Garnacho, as well as Bruno Fernandes, suggests Ten Hag, just as he did against Aston Villa on Boxing Day, has discovered his best trio in attack to unleash United's potential.

When Ten Hag deployed a front-three of Garnacho, Hojlund and Rashford against Villa, United scored three times, staging a brilliant second-half comeback at Old Trafford. On this occasion, United went one better and scored four for the second game running, following last weekend's dispatching of Newport County in the FA Cup at Rodney Parade.

Though only two members of the front-three got on the scoresheet at Molineux, the second-half contributions of Scott McTominay, who put United 3-1 up less than two minutes after coming off the bench, and Mainoo meant United plundered four goals in a Premier League away game for the first time since February 2022 - a 4-2 win over Leeds United at Elland Road under Ralf Rangnick.

Scoring goals by the bucketload has been a problem for United throughout Ten Hag's tenure, highlighted by this season's tally of just 28 in 22 league matches. They have only scored four goals on two occasions in the Premier League under the Dutchman's stewardship.

Nevertheless, though United's soft centre very nearly meant they exited the Black Country with just a point, they did, in the end, secure all three, which their performance so richly deserved. Their first-half showing was their best in a very long time.

After a stop-start January, which featured just one league game, February offers United the opportunity to put together a run of positive results in their bid to climb the table. They are still outsiders to finish in the top four, currently finding themselves eight points shy of Tottenham Hotspur, but the landscape of the Premier League standings can change quickly with a few good results.

Of course, United have been guilty of too many false dawns this season; they followed up a 2-1 win over Chelsea with a 3-0 defeat to Bournemouth three days later in December. This time around, perhaps because of the returns of Lisandro Martinez, Shaw and Casemiro, it feels different.

There was an identity to United's play at Molineux and it translated into scoring four goals in a Premier League game for the first time since May, and the first time in a Premier League away game in two years. Their attack, particularly in the first half, looked menacing, with Rashford hungry to prove a point after last week's off-field events, Hojlund producing a polished performance and Garnacho once again highlighting why he is a better fit on the right wing than Antony.

If United's performance at Molineux was a sign that everything is about to click into place, they need to prove it. West Ham United are up next and the Reds cannot afford to take their foot off the pedal after such a morale-boosting victory.

headline: Leroy Sane said I was the toughest opponent he faced but I never made it at Manchester United
body: "I didn’t play much and I wanted to. It was the best decision in the end to go somewhere else where I would get more minutes."
"When you are 22, 23, 24 years old you need to be playing.
"I didn’t play much and I wanted to.
"It was the best decision in the end to go somewhere else where I would get more minutes."
Timothy Fosu-Mensah had good intentions when he left Manchester United three years ago, but now he must wonder whether he would have been better off staying instead.
The Dutch defender is now 26 years old and is nowhere near as close to starting games on a regular basis as he would have hoped when he turned down a new contract and left to join Bayer Leverkusen.

It began well with six starts in a row following his January move in 2021. But then came the first of a string of serious injuries that have limited him to just 30 appearances in three years. He has spent 935 days injured in his professional career and has been unavailable for 146 games as a result.
FEATURE: I rejected Liverpool to sign for United and then quit City medical for Arsenal

It is staggering to realise Fosu-Mensah has still played for the United first team as many times as he has for Leverkusen and only mustered 1,014 minutes of action in the last three years. Last season, 15 appearances were spread out over just 196 minutes. He hasn't made one competitive appearance so far this campaign.

As he nears a return to fitness, he will be desperate to step out on the pitch again in the coming weeks, but Leverkusen are a very different team from when he arrived. Xabi Alonso is the manager, Jeremie Frimpong is a superstar in his preferred position and Leverkusen lead Bayern Munich in the Bundesliga title race.
It's a far cry from the hype that followed him at United when he was one of the brightest young talents in the Premier League and feared by former Man City ace Leroy Sane.

"It was before when I was playing against Kyle Walker. And Crystal Palace's right-back Timothy Fosu-Mensah, I have played against him twice this season, and even last season, he had me really well under control and I told him how happy I was to play against him," he said of his toughest opponents.
That was during one of two Premier League loan spells Fosu-Mensah would go on during his time at United, with the Dutch defender rated highly enough to get opportunities at both Palace and Fulham.

The versatile defender made his debut for United under Louis van Gaal, winning the FA Cup in his debut season as a senior player when he was just 18. He might have feared for his place when Jose Mourinho arrived the following summer but he still featured 11 times under the Portuguese coach, lifting the League Cup and the Europa League in his first term.
Those experiences made him a more developed player, even if the treatment was harsh at times.

“I spent the full [2016/17] season with the first team and as a result of that, I completed a full pre-season with them for the first time," he said. “I was still a teenager when Jose Mourinho arrived and he helped me mature into becoming a man in footballing terms.

“Jose was tough on young players with his demands but in a good way because he wanted you to be ready to represent a club the size of Manchester United. He helped make me stronger mentally and physically.
“I remember playing against Northampton Town in the early rounds of the League Cup – which we went on to win at the end of the season – and I did not have my best game.

“He subbed me after 60 minutes and we had a Europa League game coming up a week or so after the League Cup game, which I did not think I had a chance of playing in after he subbed me off. However, he started me in the Europa League game and I played the full game which gave me confidence to continue to grow at the club.
"We went on to win the Europa League against Ajax at the end of the season and that was a great achievement for the club.
“Overall, I have to say that I really enjoyed working under Jose Mourinho. He was really good with me as a young player. He is open-minded and he is a very good manager, as his career has shown.”
Mourinho's treatment of young players is well documented but what was so tough for Fosu-Mensah was that not even key ally Ole Gunnar Solskjaer could find a regular place for him in the squad.

Those two loan exits had been sanctioned by Mourinho and the second was cut short when he suffered a knee ligament injury, which saw him return to United in the closing stages of the 2018–19 season. By the time he returned, there was a new manager in the Old Trafford hot seat.

Fosu-Mensah watched from the sidelines as the United hero went about rebuilding the squad and then, against all the odds, he got opportunities he never expected due to the curtailed pandemic campaign. In June of 2020, Fosu-Mensah made his first United senior matchday squad since May 2017 as he sat on the bench in an FA Cup tie against Norwich.

A month later, with Luke Shaw and Brandon Williams both out injured, Solskjaer called on him to start at left-back ahead of Diogo Dalot against former side Palace at Selhurst Park. He would make another four appearances in the final matches of the season, including in semi-final defeats of both the FA Cup and Europa League.
The Dutch defender was now fully fit, confident, and raring to go into the new campaign. He was desperate to get his chance and he got one right away. Things didn't go according to plan.

He started right back in the opening-day defeat to Crystal Palace but after a poor performance, he was dropped again. Fosu-Mensah only featured from the bench twice more in Champions League defeats away to Istanbul Basaksehir and RB Leipzig.

He would never play for the club again. Fosu-Mensah rejected a new contract as he felt 'undervalued' by the terms offered. Those close to the player insisted he was sad to be leaving but 'excited to get a fresh start and show people what he was really capable of.'

"It was my decision," he later reiterated. "The manager was good to me but at the end, I was not playing a lot. When you are 22, 23, or 24 years old you need to be playing. I didn’t play much and I wanted to. It was the best decision in the end to go somewhere else where I would get more minutes.

“The club and the manager were good to me. I recovered from a big injury; they helped me and gave me minutes. I played in the FA Cup semi-final and the Europa League semi-final. But it’s important to play regularly and to get my opportunity in the national team too.

“Ole has been very good to me. I spoke with him because he had a big injury as a player so he knew exactly how I felt. When I played against Crystal Palace after 16 months, he was very happy for me. These were very good moments. He knew I had the quality. I have no bad things to say about him because he has been very good to me."

It's a real shame that three years later he is back where he was to begin with: looking to prove himself after another serious injury. Fosu-Mensah should be praised for taking the risk to leave the club when he had doubts about his future and if there is anyone who deserves a slice of luck, it is him.
Leverkusen and United fans will be happy to see him back. Leroy Sane might not be so happy to face him again.

headline: Getafe boss defends Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood amid Jude Bellingham 'slur' allegation
body: A La Liga investigation is underway to determine what Jude Bellingham might have said against Getafe.

Getafe manager Jose Bordalas has jumped to the defence of Mason Greenwood and called for 'respect' to be shown towards the Manchester United loanee after Jude Bellingham was reported to La Liga for allegedly aiming him a ‘slur’ at him.
The Spanish top flight has announced they have asked a lip reader to determine whether or not Real Madrid midfielder Bellingham aimed the alleged slur toward Greenwood in their midweek clash.
It all stems from an incident during Real Madrid's 2-0 win on Thursday night, when the television cameras caught Bellingham mouthing something after the ball went out of play.
LATEST: £150m trio to be removed from Premier League squad after January transfer window

A La Liga statement released following the incident read: "Getafe yesterday transferred the complaint to the La Liga match director. La Liga, as it always does on these occasions, has requested an expert report on lip reading to investigate the matter and act on the basis of what can be proven beyond doubt (by the lip reader)."
Bordalas said: ‘I know the same thing that you know. It’s not up to me, it’s the club, La Liga and the Federation that have to make an assessment about it.
"The only thing that I can say is that I ask for respect from Mason Greenwood because he is a great guy.
"He is a man who respects everyone and has exemplary behaviour.’"
If charged and found guilty by the Spanish football authorities, Bellingham could be handed a potential suspension as a result.
Greenwood has not played for United since January 2022, after allegations were made against him on social media that month.

United conducted an internal investigation after the Crown Prosecution Service announced in February last year that it had dropped charges of attempted rape, assault and coercive control. United informed Greenwood that he would have to resume his career elsewhere in August.

headline: Why Manchester United loanee Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund game
body: Manchester United's winger Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund's draw with Heidenheim in the Bundesliga on Friday night
Manchester United loanee Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund's draw with Heidenheim on Friday night due to an injury.

Sancho joined the Bundesliga giants on loan in January after a public fallout with United manager Erik ten Hag. Following the defeat to Arsenal in September, the Red Devils boss explained the winger's performances in training were behind the decision not to select him.

The 23-year-old took issue with this, branding himself a 'scapegoat' and suggesting his training performances were not below par. Despite the social media statement being deleted, Sancho refused to apologise for his comments and was promptly banished from the first team.

In January, United wasted little time getting Sancho off the books and agreed to a loan switch to his old club Dortmund. Following his arrival, the forward has made three appearances and bagged two assists in the process.
However, he did not feature in the clash yesterday due to injury. Discussing the issue, Sancho's boss Edin Terzic explained it was a muscular problem.

"Jadon currently has muscular problems in the adductor area, which is not surprising after his long break," he said. "We will wait and see how things develop over the next two days and decide at short notice whether he will travel with us to Heidenheim."
As it transpires, Sancho was not fit enough to make the journey and missed the clash. It is not clear as of yet when he will return to the starting line-up.
The winger will have two years remaining on his United contract at the end of the season. However, the forward is expected to leave the club permanently at the culmination of his loan spell.

headline: I was David Moyes' first signing at Manchester United and a tattoo damaged my career
body: Guillermo Varela was David Moyes' first signing as Man United manager and there were high hopes for the defender.

The history books show Guillermo Varela was the first signing of the post-Sir Alex Ferguson era. Varela officially became David Moyes' first signing when joining United from Penarol in June 2013, but many considered the transfer as Ferguson's parting gift.

That's because Varela had undergone a successful trial in the final months of Ferguson's reign and a deal had been negotiated before Moyes took up his position. The legendary Scot believed Varela had the potential to become an outstanding right-back, however, he was unable to nail down a regular starting position under three different United managers.
“I was younger so it was difficult to come to Manchester United and try to play at 20 years old - I'm not Rashford," Varela said in an interview with The Sun in 2019.
Varela was just 20 years old when he moved to Manchester and he spent the 2013/14 season playing in the academy before the decision was made to send him on loan.
The defender joined Real Madrid's reserve side, who were managed by Zinedine Zidane. “I was with the Castilla team under Zidane for one year," Varela said.

"I would train two or three times a week with the first team. It was magnificent. With Cristiano, Karim Benzema, Gareth Bale as well. I spoke with Cristiano about Manchester United. Chicharito (Hernández) moved at the same time with me. We lived separately but he was very helpful.”
Varela made 33 appearances for Real Madrid Castilla and he was named in the first team's squad for the Champions League. The spell was a success and a return to United followed.
Louis van Gaal was in charge by then and he provided Varela with a string of appearances, with the right-back making his United senior bow against West Ham in December 2015.
"I have been pleased with the progress of the younger players when they've been called to train with the first-team squad so I am not afraid of using them if required," Van Gaal said.

Just three days later, Varela made his first start for United when playing in a 3-2 defeat to Wolfsburg, a result which sealed the Reds' exit from the Champions League. However, Matteo Darmian was Van Gaal's first-choice right-back and he continued to be selected for the majority of games, which meant Varela had to be patient for starts.

That patience was rewarded in February 2016 when Darmian sustained an injury, which meant Varela started in the second leg of the Europa League Round of 32 against FC Midtjylland. Varela assisted Marcus Rashford in a comfortable 5-1 win and he was one of the best performers that night, which saw him retain his place for the Round of 16 clash against Liverpool.
Liverpool won the first leg 2-0 at Anfield and Varela started again in the reverse fixture, but what happened next essentially ended his time at the club.
Anthony Martial opened the scoring with a penalty in the 32nd minute, but Liverpool equalised just before half-time when Phillipe Coutinho burst down the left and went around Varela.
Coutinho made beating Varela look simple before he dinked the ball over David de Gea and that mistake was enough for Van Gaal to hook him during the interval.
"It is football," Varela later said about his performance and substitution against Liverpool. “Van Gaal gave me the chance to play so I have to say thank you. He is a crazy coach.

"He was always angry with the players but it was good. I enjoyed it. I played 11 matches. I enjoyed every single one. I played one game in the Champions League, I played in the Europa League. Playing for Manchester United is amazing. Of course, it was a dream.

“Growing up, it was always about Manchester United, ahead of Real Madrid and Barcelona, because of Diego Forlan playing there. So for a player from Uruguay, it was a dream to play for Manchester United. He was my hero.
“But I had to play more. At Manchester United, playing only one or two games a month was not good. I had to play every game and at Manchester United that was difficult.”
Varela featured in a handful of first-team and academy matches during the remainder of that season, so it wasn't a surprise to see him omitted from the 2016 FA Cup final squad.

Van Gaal was sacked after victory against Crystal Palace in that final and Jose Mourinho was named as his successor. The Portuguese took his first pre-season match against Wigan and Varela came on from the bench, but there was no room for him on the subsequent tour of China.

United embarked on their pre-season tour and Varela was sent on loan again, this time to Eintracht Frankfurt. He was now 23 and aware he needed a run of consistent matches. But disaster struck in just Varela's third appearance for Frankfurt when he suffered torn ankle ligaments, which required surgery and a screw inserted into his leg.

Varela returned to action after five months on the sidelines, but he was still struggling with pain caused by the injury, so he underwent further surgery. Although the injury meant he was unavailable for the DFB-Pokal Cup final against Borussia Dortmund, it was suggested his absence was actually due to an infected tattoo.
Varela had received fresh ink during his spell on the sidelines and it allegedly caused inflammation of his arm. Frankfurt reacted by suspending him and ordering his return to Manchester.
"My name is polluted. I wonder what Real Madrid should do with Sergio Ramos, who is tattooing every week," Varela reacted at the time, trying to protest his innocence.
"I cannot explain why I'm being so severely punished, and I'm not the only Eintracht professional to get a tattoo before the final, but only I was nailed to the cross for going against the manager.

"Before the 2016 FA Cup final [against Crystal Palace], we went out with several players and got a tattoo, and then we won. Now I wanted to repeat that because it brought us so much luck with Manchester."

Frankfurt's sporting director responded: "The club cannot tolerate that a player would defy instructions. He hurt the team. There was redness around where he had the tattoo, and blisters formed meaning he was unable to train.
"We'd been thinking about a loan extension. But that won't happen. He'll be suspended with immediate effect."

A few years later, Varela attempted to clarify the tattoo situation. “I got a tattoo at the top of my back on my neck," he said. "It was during my injury, while I was not playing, about three months before the final in May.
“[Manager] Niko Kovac said to me, 'I don't want you to get any more tattoos.' I said, 'Why? I'm injured'. He said, 'Yes, I know but you have to respect the players and the staff.'
“I said, 'Okay, I understand but I am injured.' Then when I started to play again I got this one done on my arm [a woman's face].

"He said to me, 'No, no, no. You stop here because we have the final in one week and I told you before you have to finish with your tattoos so now you are out.' I didn't get infected, that's not true. It was just because I got it.”

Varela returned to Manchester after a disappointing spell with Frankfurt but had no regrets. "I talked to Jose Mourinho and we talked about my future and what would be best for me," he told the Manchester Evening News.
"He was very sincere towards me. He told me my playing time would be little so my decision was that I preferred to go. A player needs to play and that's what I sought in Frankfurt."

Varela was sold by Mourinho in the summer of 2017 and he re-signed for Penarol. "I really learnt a lot from the way he [Mourinho] trained - the ball was always in the centre of the exercises," he said.
"The relationship was very good and I was pleasantly surprised. Maybe I expected his character when he is confronted with the press, but that was definitely not the case.
"He's always asking how everyone feels, making no difference between Rooney or a player who has just come up. He was always joking and ensuring he had a good connection between everyone and himself."
His time at United came to an underwhelming end and, at the time, a source close to the player told the MEN that he returned to his former club for 'personal tranquillity'.
"The player decided [to join Penarol] after how badly he was treated in Frankfurt. His experience in Europe was not good," they said.
Varela left having made 11 first-team appearances for United and he also scored an injury-time winner as the club's Under-21s won the academy Premier League title in 2016.
Many fans were disappointed to see Varela leave the club and he got his career back on track with Penarol before eventually returning to Europe in January 2019.

Varela signed for FC Copenhagen and it was there he admitted he would love a return to Old Trafford in the future. “It would be a dream to go back to Old Trafford. It would be a beautiful moment," he said.

"I wait for this. Maybe we will get drawn to play Manchester United - we don't know. But if we do, it would be a dream. Maybe we will meet again soon. Maybe in the Europa League, maybe in the Premier League.
“I'm still only 26. I of course want to go back to the Premier League at some point. In the future, maybe I can come back and play for Manchester United - I hope.
“I would say thank you to the fans. I want to say thank you for a beautiful four years, thank you for your support.”

Varela was denied his wish of a return to Old Trafford by the pandemic because when United drew Copenhagen in the quarter-finals of the Europa League in 2020, it was a one-off match and played at a neutral venue in Germany. Nonetheless, he started the game and was brought off in extra time.
Varela made over 50 appearances for Copenhagen and played a similar number of games when signing for Dynamo Moscow, but he desired a return to South America.
Since the summer of 2022, Varela has played for Brazilian club Flamengo and represented Uruguay at the Qatar World Cup.
He has finally found his 'personal tranquillity' at 30 years old.

headline: Manchester United player ratings as Lisandro Martinez and Kobbie Mainoo good vs Wolves
body: Man United beat Wolves in the Premier League and here are how Erik ten Hag's players rated at Molineux.

Manchester United set the pulses racing on Thursday night, beating Wolves 4-3 in dramatic fashion at Molineux. Kobbie Mainoo produced a sensational finish deep into injury time to win the game after Wolves looked to have snatched a point with Pedro Neto's 94th-minute equaliser.

United had earlier led 2-0 and 3-1, netting through the returning Marcus Rashford, Rasmus Hojlund and Scott McTominay. The win, their first Premier League success of 2024, moved United up to seventh in the Premier League standings, one point behind sixth-placed West Ham United.
Here's how the United players rated:
Andre Onana: Did not have many testing attempts to deal with in the first half and was indebted to Lisandro Martinez for avoiding another clanger. Let in more saveable goals. 4
Diogo Dalot: Reaffirmed his status as first-choice right-back with a performance reminiscent of the first half of last season. Wolves had little joy down his side. 8
Raphael Varane: A better defender with Lisandro Martinez next to him. Read the danger time and again but too easily done by Pedro Neto for the equaliser. 6
Lisandro Martinez: Organised, communicated and his mere presence elevated the performance level of teammates. Spared Onana with a vigilant clearance. 8
Luke Shaw: Showed why he makes such a huge difference with his overlapping runs and one led to Rasmus Hojlund's goal. Reined in his attacking in the second half. 8
Casemiro: Booked in the third minute but then the Casemiro of last season resurfaced. Serenaded on two separate occasions by the United fans but gave away a penalty. 7
Kobbie Mainoo: Acquitted himself well again and is benefiting from playing with Casemiro and earned approval from teammates deep into the second half. And what a goal. 8
Alejandro Garnacho: Switched the ball for the second goal but wasted some good openings. For once, one of the weaker performers. 6
Bruno Fernandes: Underpinned the front three expertly on the ball and off it in a quietly effective performance. 7
Marcus Rashford: Downed Wolves with his own shot in the fifth minute and contributed to the second goal. Now has three goals in three league games. 7
Rasmus Hojlund: An assist, a goal and a disallowed goal in the first half alone. Not remotely isolated and led the line superbly against a back three. 8
Subs
Scott McTominay: Restored United's two-goal lead from a corner. 8
Antony: A liability. 2
Harry Maguire: Came on to heckles. 5
Omari Forson: Looked a bit fazed. 5
Jonny Evans: Came on as United switched to a back three. 5
Manager
Picked his strongest-ever United side and the players did not disappoint. The Rashford call harked back to some of the bold decisions of last season that paid off. 8

headline: Ipswich Town give update on Brandon Williams' future after returning to Manchester United
body: Man United defender Brandon Williams is currently back at Carrington undergoing a 'medical assessment', but he is poised to soon return to Ipswich Town.
Ipswich Town manager Kieran McKenna has confirmed that he expects Manchester United defender Brandon Williams to return to the club within the next fortnight.

Williams, who joined the promotion-chasing Tractor Boys on a season-long loan deal last August, returned to United last month for a 'medical assessment'. Prior to his return to Carrington in mid-January, the left-back had started just three games since the start of November.

The 23-year-old encountered a series of knocks and illnesses which contributed to his lack of starts. Though talk of his loan deal at Portman Road being cut short surfaced throughout last month's transfer window, it has been decided that he will remain in Suffolk for the remainder of the season.

"We're happy that decision has been reached," said McKenna, as quoted by the East Anglian Daily Times. "He's still at United, he's probably going to be another 10 days, two weeks maximum there while he finishes off his recovery.

"We're hopeful then that we'll get back a Brandon Williams in a better place from a physical point of view and we know that can be a big addition to the group. He can hopefully help us in the latter stages of the season."

Williams, who has scored two goals during his loan spell with the Championship side, has racked up 17 appearances in league and cup so far this season. However, he has made just five appearances in total since the beginning of November.

Though Williams is a left-back by trade, the former Norwich City loanee has also stored a collection of appearances at right-back under his belt this season. He scored an outstanding solo goal from the right-back berth in Ipswich's 4-2 win over Preston North End in October.

Ipswich are currently second in the Championship table, less than 12 months after clinching promotion from League One. They are 10 points behind table-toppers Leicester City and one point clear of third-placed Southampton.

headline: Tequila banging but 'something else is stirring' - national media verdict on dramatic Man United win
body: Manchester United earned their first Premier League win of 2024 with a hard-fought victory over Wolves and here is what the national media thought of the win
Manchester United made it difficult for themselves once again but Erik ten Hag's side earned a vital 4-3 win over Wolves on Thursday to move up to seventh in the Premier League.

Having come into the game without a win in the league since Boxing Day, all eyes were on United and Marcus Rashford. The forward returned to Ten Hag's squad after missing the Newport County win following an "internal matter".
Rashford took five minutes to make an immediate impact with a well-placed effort past Jose Sa. Rasmus Hojlund made it three goals in three games to make it 2-0 in the first-half.

A controversial penalty to Wolves gave the hosts a lifeline before Scott McTominay added a third in the 75th minute. However, the Reds threw away their lead in the space of 10 minutes as Pedro Neto's 95th minute equaliser looked as though it would deny United all three points.
Step up, Kobbie Mainoo. After scoring his first goal for the club at the weekend, the midfielder showed unreal skill and technique to curl the ball into the bottom corner two minutes later.
Here's what the national media made of United's last-gasp win at Molineux.

Ben Fisher, of The Guardian, wrote: "For so long the obvious thing was to laud Rashford’s goalscoring return after his latest ticking-off from Ten Hag but, zoom out a little, and there were glimmers of something else stirring beneath the surface. For the best part of an hour, United made rather compelling viewing.

"Rashford and Rasmus Højlund capped slick team moves. Ten Hag acknowledged this was probably his strongest starting lineup of the season and a team brimming with World Cup and Champions League winners and a couple of the game’s brightest talents seemed to click.

"Ten Hag insisted it was a matter of case closed when it came to Rashford and his unlicensed gallivanting in Belfast nightspots this time last week but, in reality, all eyes were on how the 26-year-old would fare on his return to the team.

"The answer was a resounding one, Rashford tormenting Semedo, Wolves’ right-wing back. Wolves, Gary O’Neil said, anticipated Rashford would start and so he did, which perhaps explains the pointed pre-match playlist that featured both The Champs’ and Terrorvision’s songs by the name of Tequila."

Sam Wallace, of The Telegraph, wrote: "This was the kind of thrilling late, great win that was once the hallmark of Manchester United, although this Erik ten Hag team were only obliged to do it this way because they had conspired to squander the advantage so many times.

"It was a five-man United defence to see out nine minutes of time added on and they still managed to be outnumbered in the counterattack for Neto’s goal. Yet just as Wolves thought they had secured the draw, Mainoo took a pass from Forson and scored the goal of his life.
"From nowhere in particular on the left he went around the substitute Joao Gomes, slipped the ball through the legs of Max Kilman and dispatched the winner past Jose Sa."
Chris Wheeler, of the Daily Mail, wrote: "This was a massive win for them and not just because the gap to the top-four is only eight points now.

"They seem to be gathering momentum at a time when Ten Hag desperately needs it. If this wasn’t his strongest team, then it was pretty close to it now Lisandro Martinez, Casemiro and Luke Shaw are back in action.
"The old frailties still linger, though, and United cannot keep on giving up leads like this if they are going to salvage anything from this strangest of seasons."

headline: Erik ten Hag was right about some Manchester United players but needed Kobbie Mainoo to prove it
body: Kobbie Mainoo scored a sensational winner for Man Utd at Wolves in what was a much-improved performance from Erik ten Hag's side.
If Manchester United's season is going to turn on anything, then surely it is the three minutes of madness at Molineux that saw the best and the worst of them on a chaotic, cathartic night.

This was a game United had bossed only to throw away. They produced one of their best performances of the season but managed to lay bare all of their flaws to concede a third goal in stoppage time. It was lamentable from Antony, tactically naive from many and poor from Andre Onana. It was a season in microcosm.
But maybe, just maybe, times are changing. For once the mistakes didn't cost United. They got up off the canvas to throw one more haymaker, in the form of a moment of magic from Kobbie Mainoo.

Just as the 3,000 supporters in the away end were beginning to lament the soft centre of their team once again, the teenager from Stockport sent them wild. He turned away from one challenge, cut inside another, opened up a shooting angle and picked his spot. It was a quite brilliant goal from a midfielder who doesn't turn 19 until April.
And just as Ten Hag had suggested, United had begun to look like their old selves, albeit with a few of those flaws still on display.

The Dutchman hadn't shied away from the pressure recently. His returning stars in January were going to be like "five or six new signings" and the squad he could pick at Wolves was "probably the strongest" since he had been at the club. At a time when the United manager was under pressure, he embraced it.

Ten Hag's job security has been getting weaker all season and he went into this trip to Molineux with United ninth in the Premier League. Defeat to an in-form Wolves would have left them 10th well past the halfway stage.

At a time when Sir Dave Brailsford is omnipresent at Carrington and Ineos are driving up standards, the spotlight on Ten Hag has been inescapable, even if his early discussions with Brailsford and Sir Jim Ratcliffe have been positive.

Sharing a vision for the future and an understanding of what is wrong is all well and good, however. Ten Hag was only ever going to strengthen his grip on the United job by getting results. A desperate season simply had to improve.
With the treatment room clearing, this felt like a jumping-off point. Day one of Ten Hag's true audition for his own job. This morning he will feel a little more secure in the post.

“For the first time since I was the manager, we can pick a team from the squad that is probably the strongest," Ten Hag had said of this game in the aftermath of Sunday's scrappy win at Newport. In his 94th game in charge, this was the best team he had picked.

Of those still unavailable, there is an argument Mason Mount would make a difference. Ten Hag clearly had his reasons for spending £55million on him this summer, but Mainoo has made a better fist of doing that job than the England international. Other than that, this is the best team Ten Hag has picked.

He had his new goalkeeper in situ. His first-choice full-backs alongside his World Cup-winning centre-backs of Lisandro Martinez and Raphael Varane. Casemiro was patrolling midfield with Mainoo the link point to Bruno Fernandes. Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford carried a threat out wide and Rasmus Hojlund is finding his feet through the middle.

True to his word, with key men back and those rhythms established, United began to perform. This was, by some distance, their most coherent, most structured performance of the season. They were dangerous going forward and defended well until the meltdown began in the final 20 minutes.

The tone was set by Rashford's early redemption and control established through a slick move to bring Hojlund his third goal in as many Premier League starts. But it was the quality of some of United's football that stood out.

Dalot was regularly drifting back into those central midfield roles, at one point taking station in an attacking midfield area to chest down a drilled pass forward from Casemiro. Fernandes picked it up and United had turned defence into attack with one good pass and one piece of clever movement.

Casemiro was excellent, delivering a performance that suggested his United obituaries might have been penned too soon. The 31-year-old had struggled in the first half of the season but shrugged off an early booking at Molineux to dominate midfield. His passing was crisp and his positioning shrewd. He provided the defensive shield that had been beyond him before his injury in November and was unfortunate to concede the penalty from which Pablo Sarabia brought Wolves back into the game, before Scott McTominay scored.

How Ten Hag needs last season's version of his £70million signing to be back permanently. The ability to salvage this season lay chiefly with Martinez and Casemiro and how close they get to recapturing their levels from 2022/23.

On this evidence - albeit against a poor Wolves side - they might just have decisive contributions to make. It was telling they weren't on the pitch as the game unravelled. Max Kilman took advantage of some sloppy defending from a corner before Wolves somehow managed to launch a counterattack in the 95th minute.
Antony lost the ball softly and too many United players were caught too far up the pitch when protecting a lead. Onana didn't do enough to stop Neto's shot at his near post.

But Molineux was silenced by Mainoo. There have been too many false dawns this season to get too carried away, but this was as positive a night as any this campaign. This result was built on more secure foundations than those dramatic wins against Brentford, Chelsea and Aston Villa and those unconvincing ones against Sheffield United, Luton and Fulham.
They have to improve defensively, but this was encouraging for United and for Ten Hag, at a time when he really needed his luck to turn.

headline: West Ham confirm two attackers will miss Manchester United fixture
body: West Ham United manager David Moyes has issued the latest on the injury front ahead of Sunday's clash with Man United at Old Trafford.
West Ham United will once again be without Lucas Paquetá and Michail Antonio through injury when they face Manchester United at Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon, manager David Moyes has confirmed.

Paquetá, who was heavily linked with a move to Manchester City last summer, has missed each of the Hammers' last three matches with a calf injury. He last featured in the 1-1 draw with Bristol City in the third round of the FA Cup on January 7.

The Brazilian has been a key contributor to the Londoners' attacking play this season, racking up five goals and six assists in all competitions. He provided an assist in the Hammers' 2-0 win over United at the London Stadium two days before Christmas.

As for Antonio, he is making progress in his recovery from a knee injury, but Sunday's trip to M16 will come too soon for him. He has not played since the Hammers' 3-2 win over his former club Nottingham Forest on November 12.

"It's a really quick turnaround from Thursday's game," Moyes conceded, speaking at his pre-match press conference on Friday morning. "We're getting ourselves back together quickly and hopefully everyone will come through okay.
"There's no more update in terms of injuries. We're still dealing with the lads who are injured.
"We've not had any more from the medical team to suggest that [Paquetá] is going to be back. He's been out for a few weeks and I don’t think he’ll be back for this weekend.

"Michail Antonio is coming on a bit more. He's running on the grass now. He's not worked with or trained with the team but he’s training outside. I couldn't give a projected return date at this moment though."

headline: Marcus Rashford made one big change to his game for Manchester United vs Wolves
body: Man Utd won a thrilling and chaotic game 4-3 at Wolves on a night when Marcus Rashford delivered some redemption after his Belfast antics.
Rashford's redemption

The stadium PA was going through his own rehearsed routine as the Manchester United squad went through their final warm-up at Molineux. One wonders whether Marcus Rashford's musical knowledge allowed him to pick up the cover version of Terrorvision's Tequila or the song of the same name by The Champs.

A week ago Rashford was downing Tequila in the bars of Belfast and was a matter of hours from waking up bleary-eyed in the city and phoning in sick for United training. He would subsequently miss the trip to Newport County and has been in the spotlight ever since.

After showdown talks on Monday, United said Rashford had "taken responsibility" for his actions and been disciplined, but was available for selection. It was still a surprise to see him in the starting XI at Wolves.

But if he felt he owed people a performance he began to deliver inside five minutes. When Rasmus Hojlund teed him up for the shot from the edge of the area the chance was still a difficult one, but Rashford picked his spot beautifully, leaving Jose Sa with no chance. He ran over to the away end to celebrate, although showed little emotion as he stood in front of those jubilant supporters.

This was easily the most engaged and enthused he has looked on the pitch this season, however, and if he was fearing some brickbats from the away end, midway through the first half they were serenading him with a sustained chant of "Rashford's on the p**s".

By then he had sprinted back to close down Nelson Semedo and had a detailed tactical discussion with Rasmus Hojlund. He then helped create Hojlund's goal with a perfectly weighted pass to Luke Shaw on the overlap.
Casemiro reminds us of his class

Casemiro has been back in the side for two games and already he's collected two more bookings, taking his tally to five in his last six appearances, which also includes that Champions League red card against Galatasaray.
He was late to a tackle against Newport County on Sunday and was booked very early at Molineux when he got a tackle against Semedo all wrong and upended the full-back.

But this was a much better performance on the ball from the Brazilian, who picked some good passes from deep areas and controlled the play at times. He was also better defensively and the away end sang his name when he stood up to Matheus Cunha as he attempted to dribble through him late in the first half.

He was also unlucky to give a penalty away for a trip on Pedro Neto when contact seemed minimal. Jarred Gillett pointed to the spot on the pitch and despite a lengthy VAR review, there was not enough evidence to overturn the decision, although there was no indication of any contact.
Seeing games out
It was always going to take something special to overtake United's injury-time comeback against Brentford for the most dramatic end to a game this season, but this might have done it.

Kobbie Mainoo's magnificent winner will live long in the memory but United should be kicking themselves at how difficult they made it. The goal they conceded to Max Kilman was soft and the equaliser was awful.

It was naive to be caught on the break from your own corner in the 95th minute when protecting a 3-2 lead, and it's not the first time United have been poor defensively from their own corners this season.
They got away with it, but as good as aspects of this performance were, they have to tighten up defensively if they are to make up ground to the top five.
Martinez's influence is clear

Of all the players United have missed this season, Lisandro Martinez has been one of the most costly, with the 23 games he missed with a recurrence of his foot injury affecting the offensive and defensive stability of the team.
Martinez has been excellent since signing from Ajax but his quality and calmness in possession is just as vital to the build-up as his reading of the game and aggression is to defending.

Losing Martinez certainly didn't help Andre Onana's integration into the side but since his return it's been noticeable how much better United are looking as they pass out from deep areas. Onana is finding Martinez far more often than he ever went short to Jonny Evans and it's giving the team options as they build the play.

The Argentine showed his defensive brilliance as well with a superb goalline clearance after Kilman had beaten Onana to a free-kick. His header was heading for the back of the net until Martinez came to the rescue.
Shaw and Rashford link-up

Who knows what brought the best out of Rashford on Thursday night, but it will have helped him having Luke Shaw behind him once again. There's little doubt that Rashford produces his best football on the left when he is in tandem with the excellent Shaw.
Twice in the early stages they linked up well, with Rashford holding the ball while he waited for his full-back to go past him on the overlap. The second goal came from the same combination.

Shaw is one of several key men returning to the team at the moment and he might be able to get the best out of Rashford, who is beginning to find some form of his own with five goal contributions in his last five appearances.
United had to muddle through without a natural left-back with Shaw sidelined, but he is one of the key members of this squad and his understanding of how to play with Rashford is also a key weapon.

headline: Manchester United's quiet January transfer window lays down the gauntlet for Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United did not make any new signings during the January transfer window despite a disappointing season so far, so the pressure is on Sir Jim Ratcliffe to deliver this summer
Heading into the January transfer window, Manchester United supporters were keen to see new faces.

United have underperformed so far this season as injuries, a loss of form and disciplinary matters plagued the squad, leading to a Champions League exit and an uphill battle to secure a top-four finish. Erik ten Hag admitted to wanting a new striker in the January transfer window following the victory over Wolverhampton Wanderers in the Premier League. Alas, United stuck to their guns this winter.

Before the window opened, club officials stressed they were not interested in conducting major business in January - and that stance preceded no new signings. However, this did not stop the club from completing a host of departures: several academy players and fringe stars departed on loan, notably Donny van de Beek, Hannibal Mejbri and Facundo Pellistri.

The biggest exit from a United perspective came as Jadon Sancho left on loan to join Borussia Dortmund. Crucially though, the Bundesliga giants have confirmed they will find it difficult to make this switch permanent in the summer. This news, coupled with the lack of signings means this window could be considered below par among the fanbase. Sir Jim Ratcliffe and INEOS have a huge summer ahead of them, with multiple areas of the squad needing quality.

By the time the next window opens, Ratcliffe should have had his investment in United ratified by the Premier League and his staff will be tasked with rebuilding the club. Plenty of new signings will be expected but departures shall also be necessary to shake off the burden of Premier League Profit and Sustainability Regulations (PSR).
The big question is: what do you think of United's January business? Let us know in our poll above, and get involved in the debate in the comments section.

headline: Former Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini retires from football
body: Marouane Fellaini arrived at Old Trafford from Everton in August 2013 and went on to score 22 goals in 177 appearances.

Former Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini has announced his retirement from professional football at the age of 36. Fellaini became David Moyes' first United signing in a £27.5 million move from Everton on deadline day in 2013. He went on to win the FA Cup, the League Cup and the Europa League during his five-and-a-half years at Old Trafford, scoring 22 goals in 177 appearances.
The former Everton midfielder was criticised for much of his United career but has been given more credit in later years than he did at the time.

Fellaini was mocked for what he represented as much as anything, with United often resorting to him when they ran out of ideas in the closing stages of matches and grew desperate. He was also synonymous with the club's transfer failure, having ended up being United's sole summer signing in a season in which the club finished seventh and Moyes was sacked after just 10 months in charge.
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag
His best spell of football came when he won three trophies under Jose Mourinho and proved to be an effective option from the bench.

Fellaini only played 31 minutes under United caretaker coach Ole Gunnar Solskjaer before he was sold to Chinese Super League side Shandong Luneng Taishan in a deal worth around £10million back in 2019.

Speaking after his exit, the Belgian insisted he had no regrets about leaving the club after Mourinho had been sacked: "He (Solskjaer) didn’t have a conversation with me if I will play or not. I signed a new contract for two years, one of the best managers in the world wanted me to stay.
"But after that, when a new manager comes and I’m not in his plans, of course it was time for me to leave and I don’t regret it at all."
He was also part of the Belgium side that finished third at the 2018 World Cup, during an international career that saw him score 18 goals in 87 appearances.

headline: Gary Lineker's four-word summary of Manchester United 'transfer target' speaks volumes
body: Manchester United shall head into the summer transfer window needing to reinvest in their squad after a quiet January and with INEOS' arrival imminent
Match of the Day host Gary Lineker has hailed 'very, very special talent' Michael Olise amid Manchester United transfer links.

The Crystal Palace winger was at his best on Tuesday night as he scored and assisted two in Roy Hodgson's side's 3-2 victory over Sheffield United at Selhurst Park. Olise's star turn in South London took his tally to six goals and three assists in just ten appearances this campaign.

Last weekend, our colleagues at Football.London revealed Olise would prefer a transfer to United in the summer. It is expected the forward will depart Palace at the end of the season considering his form compared to the club's.

Despite keen interest from Chelsea to bring the winger in, Olise would lean towards Erik ten Hag's side because he is a boyhood supporter of the Reds. It is understood last summer, Mauricio Pochettino's side triggered his £35m release clause but the forward chose to stay at Palace and sign a new deal.

Should United choose to make a move for the forward this summer, Lineker has given his seal of approval to the deal. Speaking on this week's The Rest is Football podcast, he said: "A couple of the best performances we have seen in midweek came from two young Crystal Palace stars, [Eberechi] Eze and Olise.

"They are fabulously talented. I had lunch with Steve Parish last week actually and he was extolling the virtues of Michael Olise, saying that he thinks he is going to be very, very special talent and I wouldn’t disagree with him."

headline: Football finance expert claims Manchester United owners still want to join Super League
body: Man Utd were one of the most prominent clubs to back the Super League before they withdrew 48 hours later.
A football finance expert has claimed that Manchester United would still love to join a Super League but will not risk another 'hostile reception' from supporters.

Last December, a ruling decided the European football governing body had no legal right to block the inception of the Super League, and management company A22 announced plans for a 64-team competition to effectively gazump the Champions League.

United co-chairman Joel Glazer was one of the three figures who endorsed the breakaway league when it was announced in April 2021. After a fierce backlash from supporters, United withdrew from their planned participation, along with the other five Premier League clubs.
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag
United supporters protested against the Super League more ardently than any other fanbase, forcing the postponement of their May 2021 Premier League home fixture against Liverpool.
Two months ago, United insisted they remain committed to competing in Uefa competitions. However, finance expert Kieran Maguire insists club owners would still love to join the proposed competition.

“There’s no doubt that the owners of Liverpool, Man United and the other sneaky six would love to be in the Super League, but I think they all know from the very hostile reaction of fans that this would not be an acceptable decision,” Maguire told Football Insider.
“I think what we will see is perhaps a Super League which doesn’t involve English clubs to begin with.

“If this has a significant detrimental impact on the value of Uefa’s rights then we will start to see a whisper campaign that clubs cannot afford to not be involved because Real Madrid and Barcelona are.
"It’ll be interesting to see who is going to sign up because I would imagine there’d be a very hostile reaction from German football fans.
“English football fans have clearly voted with their voices and their feet when the first variant of the Super League emerged.“
In the wake of the Super League ruling last December, the British Government reacted by saying it would bring forward legislation to stop English clubs from joining a breakaway competition.

A statement issued by the Department for Media, Culture and Sport read: “The attempt to create a breakaway competition was a defining moment in English football and was universally condemned by fans, clubs and the Government.
“We took decisive action at the time by triggering the fan-led review of football governance, which called for the creation of a new independent regulator for English football.
"We will shortly be bringing forward legislation that makes this a reality, and will stop clubs from joining any similar breakaway competitions in the future.”

headline: Manchester United perform ticket policy U-turn after complaints
body: The official independent Manchester United Supporters Trust have ensured a controversial policy has been removed.
Manchester United have removed a controversial policy from their ticketing terms and conditions after a backlash from supporters.

United have told supporters that season ticket prices will increase by five per cent next season, and they also threatened to take away concession renewal rights if they did not personally attend 17 out of 19 Premier League home matches next season. The club offers discounted season ticket prices for concessions, but originally did so on the agreement that they must attend the majority of eligible matches to benefit.

Season ticket terms and conditions issued by the club read: "Ticket holders that hold a discounted or concessionary season ticket must personally attend at least 89% of all Premier League home matches that take place at the stadium during the season in order to be able to purchase a discounted or concessionary season ticket for the following season."
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag

Those terms would therefore require a ticket holder to be in attendance for 17 home matches across a Premier League season if they wanted to keep their seat, a controversial rule given the difficulty of travelling to matches across an entire campaign, particularly with frequent scheduling changes.

Taking to social media, the official independent Manchester United Supporters Trust (MUST) confirmed they had previously raised the issue with the club, who agreed not to enforce it. However, the matter was raised once again when the threat was printed in the latest ticketing terms and conditions.
MUST raised the issue with United once again on Friday night and say the club have now agreed to remove the clause altogether to avoid any further confusion.

It means concessionary season tickets are no longer restricted, and the personal rule of attending 89 per cent of matches is no longer binding. Ticket holders can sell back, transfer, or donate their tickets on a game basis, and all of this counts as usage.

headline: Sunderland director explains failed loan bid for Manchester United starlet Amad
body: Amad shone on loan with Championship side Sunderland last season but Man Utd didn't want him to go back.
Sunderland technical director Kristjaan Speakman insists the Championship club did all they could to try and bring Amad back on loan from Manchester United.
The Black Cats were eager to bring the Ivorian back to the club on loan last month, but United decided against sanctioning another loan exit for the winger.
Amad proved to be a real fan favourite during his season with Sunderland a year ago, netting 14 goals and registering four assists as they reached the play-off semi finals.
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag
Sunderland did all they could to try and bring him back to the Stadium of Light for the remainder of the season, but Erik ten Hag decided to keep him as Facundo Pellistri left on loan instead.
“Amad would have been one of those three or four targets [that we were working on] but there are factors we have no control over,” Speakman told Sunderland Nation.
“I think you've seen, first of all, in terms of the market over the January window, it's been, I think the phrase that's been commonly used, is it’s been a fairly dormant market.
“There's not been as many transactions. And ultimately then you're waiting on player availability most of the time, whether that's on a permanent basis or a loan basis.
“It ran its course that he wasn't available. He's not turned up anywhere else. We stayed in that for as long as we possibly could.
“In hindsight you could say that was to the detriment of maybe signing another player earlier on, but we felt that was a choice we had to make and we were comfortable with that choice.”

headline: West Ham boss David Moyes gives verdict on Manchester United's style of play and Erik ten Hag
body: West Ham United manager David Moyes has been discussing Man United's development under Erik ten Hag ahead of Sunday's Premier League meeting at Old Trafford.
West Ham United manager David Moyes says Erik ten Hag deserves credit for trying to enforce a style of play on Manchester United.

Moyes made the admission ahead of Sunday's Premier League meeting between the two clubs at Old Trafford. United moved to within a point of the Hammers in the standings after Thursday night's enthralling 4-3 win over Wolves at Molineux.

The victory in the Black Country, which marked United's first league triumph of 2024, coincided with the likes of Lisandro Martinez, Luke Shaw and Casemiro all starting in the league for the first time since recovering from respective injury problems. United were much-improved and their first-half showing saw them produce the best football they had played all season.

Moyes, who guided the Hammers to a 2-0 win over United before Christmas, has been in Ten Hag's shoes and understands the demands that come with managing the Reds. Though the Dutchman has got a lot of work to do to try and salvage United's season, Moyes believes he is starting to implement the style of play he wants to see.
Speaking at his pre-match press conference on Friday morning, Moyes said: "Erik ten Hag is in a privileged position to be manager of Manchester United. I think he understands and respects that.
"I think he is trying to enforce how he wants the team to play and work, and you have to give him credit for that. When you're in that job, you are under a lot of pressure.
"You are expected to win and you are expected to perform well. He understands that.
"I think he's trying to get himself this period and then start building again, and they certainly picked up a good result against Wolverhampton Wanderers on Thursday."
On his side's ambitions for the trip to M16, Moyes added: "We played very well against Manchester United when we played them at London Stadium.
"We're now going to Old Trafford, which has always been a notoriously hard place to get results. We'll go there and try to put on a good performance."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund identifies 'selfish' switch helping Manchester United goals return
body: Rasmus Hojlund had to wait until Boxing Day to score his first goal for Man Utd in the Premier League but he has now scored in three successive league outings.

The goals are finally starting to flow for Rasmus Hojlund. After 14 Premier League games without a goal, the £72millon striker has now scored in three successive league outings and his Boxing Day breakthrough against Aston Villa is increasingly looking like the moment the floodgates opened.

Hojlund was the striker who could only score in Europe until then, which wasn't ideal given United were out of Europe by December. But his acrobatic strike to cap off Christmas was celebrated with abandon and lifted a weight from his shoulders. He has kicked on since then.

He missed the very next game - a defeat at Nottingham Forest - through illness but it didn't halt his momentum. He missed some chances in the FA Cup third round at Wigan but has since scored against Tottenham and Wolves in the Premier League, either side of netting at Newport County.

It's taken his tally for the season to nine and a return of 0.42 goals per 90 minutes in a team that has spent most of the year struggling suddenly looks a lot more respectable. Although his lengthy domestic drought was a concern, Hojlund's five goals in the Champions League showed he had the talent to thrive, which is why his scoring spurt in the Premier League has been more a case of relief than affirmation that he is cut out for this level.

Asked if he felt the goals would begin to come more easily once he had his first, Hojlund said: "Yes and no. I knew I could score goals and I’d shown it in the Champions League and at my previous clubs, but of course opening the account it’s always like ‘ok, I can do it’."

His winner against Villa was smartly taken and his rasping finish early on against Spurs was another indication of the talent that convinced Erik ten Hag to take an expensive punt on a striker still relatively inexperienced at the highest level. His goal in United's thrilling and chaotic 4-3 win at Wolves on Thursday was from the scrappier variety but they all count and he is beginning to feel at home now in a team that has its best players returning from injury.
"We’re starting to understand each other better into the team and I think I’m getting used to the Premier League and the tempo and how we play as a team and these sort of things," he said.
"Of course [it was going to take time], but if you ask me I would have loved to score my first goal in September or October."

Hojlund's goals have come at a point when United are threatening to find some form. Although they nearly blew it, the performance at Wolves was one of their best of the season and they have won four of their last six games, while also drawing with Tottenham in that run.
The former Atalanta striker believes there are signs the team is starting to click now and that the forwards are finding a nice balance between going solo and providing for each other.

"It’s good to see, I hope we can keep going, keep the confidence in the team, keep providing for each other. I think that’s key, we’re being selfish when we have to but we also play for each other," said Hojlund.
"Offensively, I think we were very great. We created a lot of chances [against Wolves] and four goals is a lot and we could score even more so very happy with that."

headline: I watched Manchester United's dramatic win and saw four signs of much-needed squad unity
body: Here are the moments you might have missed from Man United's thrilling 4-3 win over Wolves in the Premier League on Thursday evening.
Manchester United recorded their first Premier League win of 2024 on Thursday night, beating Wolves 4-3 in dramatic fashion at Molineux.

After Pedro Neto appeared to have earned Wolves a point, making it 3-3 with 95 minutes on the clock, Kobbie Mainoo produced a moment of magic to score his first Premier League goal two minutes later. He curled a shot into the far corner from just inside the penalty area.

United had earlier led 2-0 and 3-1, netting through Marcus Rashford, Rasmus Hojlund and Scott McTominay. The latter put the Reds 3-1 up less than two minutes after stepping off the bench. The win, which was fully merited, moved United up to seventh in the Premier League standings, one point behind sixth-placed West Ham United.

Though the scoreline suggested it was a close battle that the Reds narrowly edged, their performance was much more convincing, meaning they now have a platform to try and build on, starting against West Ham this weekend. Below, MEN Sport has highlighted some of the moments you may not have spotted from the seven-goal contest at Molineux.
